objdescid.origination: Georg Jacob Vollweiler(?)printer. Printing a lithograph requires a special press. Vollweiler, the London agent for Alois Senefelder, the inventor of lithography, may have supplied Blake with the lithographic stone and also printed this work.

objinfo.medium: lithography on white lyas stoneAccording to an inscription by George Cumberland on the verso of an impression of *Enoch* formerly in the collection of Edward Croft-Murray and now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Blake delineated his design with a mixture of asphaltum and linseed oil, rather than the customary chalk or lithographic ink, on white lyas stone.
objinfo.framelines: 1A single framing line is contiguous with the edges of the image.
objinfo.binding: Mounted on a leaf of wove paper in turn bound as leaf 93 in a volume of miscellaneous lithographs by other artists.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Thomas Fisher (according to the British Museum catalogue); the dealer James Rimell & Son, bound into a collection of early lithographs and one engraving; the volume sold by Rimell in July 1874 to the British Museum.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this lithograph, an old male figure sits facing forward on a raised plinth-like platform in the center of the composition. He has long hair and a beard and wears a gown. His arms are extended downward and he appears to hold an open book against his lower legs. His legs are bent with his right knee on the floor in a kneeling position. His left foot is visible beneath his gown. He may sit in a chair, the arms of which are visible on either side of his legs. This figure is Enoch, who is described in Genesis 5:22-29 as having walked with God. Several sources describe Enoch as the first man to learn writing. Three younger, smaller figures sit or stand around the central old man, who may be their father. All hold instruments of an art. The figure at right, who appears to be nude, sits facing left and bends forward. The figure is likely male(?) and has short hair. His arms are bent and rest on his legs, which are also bent beneath him. He holds an open book and, in his right hand, a long pen or quill. A second nude, male figure stands facing left to the left of the old male figure. He has short hair and bends his head forward. He holds a paintbrush in his right hand and a palette in his left. Below and to the left of this figure, a female figure sits facing right on the corner of the raised platform. She has long hair and wears a gown. She is bending forward and rests a lyre between her legs. She appears to play the instrument with her right hand, which is raised. Her legs are bent beneath her. The platform on which these four figures sit or stand has two tiers. Each tier has an arch-like design on the front. The ground below the platform along the lower edge of the design is grassy. Two groups of flying or hovering figures who may be angels frame the central group. The pair of figures at right fly or hover facing left and away. The rightmost figure, who has short hair and wears a gown, turns his(?) head to face left. He may raise his left arm to point toward the tablet or piece of paper held by the figure at left with his left hand. His left foot is visible beneath his gown. The second figure from the right appears to be a nude male who twists slightly to the right, perhaps to look toward his companion at right. He has short curly hair and extends his straight legs backward slightly. He holds a page of Hebrew text in his left hand. The group of three flying or hovering figures at left face right. The rightmost of these figures is a male figure with curly hair. He appears to wear a semi-transparent gown with a long slit rising above his right leg. His head is bent down. His arms are bent and at his side, and he appears to hold a scroll or piece of paper with both hands. He may be reading. His legs are crossed at the ankle and his feet are pointed down. The leftmost figure in this group, who has long hair, hovers or flies facing right and wears a long gown or cloak, obscuring the body from the shoulders down. The figure's gender is indistinguishable. The figure's right leg appears to be bent backward beneath the gown or cloak. Behind this figure at right, the second figure from the left faces right and forward and appears to have short, curly hair. Only the head of this figure is visible. Leafy, twisted grapevines grow upward along the sides of the design and extend partially toward the center of the top edge. A large cluster of grapes is visible at the base of each plant in the lower right and left corners. Diagonal lines, likely suggesting beams of light or radiance, emanate from the top center of the design where there is an area of void. The edges of clouds may be visible against both the upper halves of the right and left sides of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: In this lithograph, an old male figure sits facing forward on a raised platform in the center of the composition. He has long hair and a beard and wears a gown. His arms are extended downward and he appears to hold an open book against his lower legs. His legs are bent with his right knee on the floor in a kneeling position. His left foot is visible beneath his gown. He may sit in a chair whose arms are visible on either side of his legs. This figure may be the biblical figure Enoch, who is described in Genesis 5:22-29 as having walked with God. Several sources describe Enoch as the first man to learn writing.

The old male figure in the center of the design holds an open book against his lower legs. Four Hebrew letters are visible on the left page of the book. This figure may sit in a chair, the arms of which are visible on either side of his legs.

Three younger, smaller figures sit or stand around the central old man, who may be their father. All hold instruments of an art. The figure at right, who appears to be nude, sits facing left and bends forward with head down. The figure is likely male(?) and has short hair. His arms are bent and rest on his legs, which are also bent beneath him. He holds an open book and, in his right hand, a long pen or quill. He may be writing.
The seated youth to the right of the central male figure holds an open book on his knees and a quill or pen in his right hand.

Three younger, smaller figures sit or stand around the central old man, who may be their father. All hold instruments of an art. A second nude, male figure stands facing left to the left of the old male figure. He has short hair and bends his head forward. He holds a paintbrush in his right hand and a palette in his left. He may be painting.
The standing youth to the left of the central male figure holds a palette with paint in his left hand and a brush in his right hand.

Three younger, smaller figures sit or stand around the central old man, who may be their father. All hold instruments of an art. On the leftmost corner of the central platform, a female figure sits facing right. She has long hair and wears a gown. She is bending forward and rests a lyre between her legs. She appears to play the instrument with her right hand, which is raised. Her legs are bent beneath her.
The youth seated on the leftmost corner of the central platform holds a lyre in her lap. She appears to play the instrument with her raised right hand.
The plinth-like platform, possibly made of carved stone, on which the central four figures sit or stand has two tiers or steps. Each tier has an arch design.

The platform on which these four figures sit or stand has two tiers. Each tier has an arch-like design on the front and may be covered with grass(?). The ground below the platform along the lower edge of the design is also grassy.

Two groups of flying or hovering figures who may be angels frame the central group. The pair of figures at right fly or hover facing left and away. The rightmost figure, who has short hair and wears a gown, turns his(?) head to face left. He may raise his left arm to point toward the page of Hebrew text held by the figure at left with his left hand. He appears to look toward the text, which he may read. His left foot is visible beneath his gown.

Two groups of flying or hovering figures who may be angels frame the central group. The pair of figures at right fly or hover facing left and away. The second figure from the right appears to be a nude male who twists slightly to the right, perhaps to look toward his companion at right. He has short curly hair and extends his straight legs backward slightly. He holds a page of Hebrew text in his left hand. Both arms are bent upward.

The second figure from the right who flies or hovers holds in his left hand a piece of paper or tablet containing two lines of Hebrew text (see the Transcription). The figure to his right appears to point toward the text.

Two groups of flying or hovering figures who may be angels frame the central group. The group of three figures at left face right. The rightmost of these figures is a male figure with curly hair. He appears to wear a semi-transparent gown with a long slit rising above his right leg. His head is bent down. His arms are bent and at his side, and he appears to hold a scroll or piece of paper with both hands. He may be reading. His legs are crossed at the ankle and his feet are pointed down.
The third figure from the left who flies or hovers facing right holds with both hands a scroll or piece of paper which he may be reading.

Two groups of flying or hovering figures who may be angels frame the central group. The group of three figures at left face right. The leftmost figure in this group, who has long hair and perhaps an open mouth, hovers or flies facing right and wears a long gown or cloak, obscuring the body from the shoulders down. The figure's gender is indistinguishable. The figure's right leg appears to be bent backward beneath the gown or cloak.

Two groups of flying or hovering figures who may be angels frame the central group. The group of three figures at left face right. The middle figure in this group faces right and forward and appears to have short, curly hair. Only the head of this figure is visible.

Leafy, twisted grapevines grow upward along the sides of the design and extend partially toward the center of the top edge. A large cluster of grapes is visible at the base of each plant in the lower right and left corners.

Diagonal lines, likely suggesting beams of light or radiance, emanate from the top center of the design where there is an area of void. The edges of clouds may be visible against both the upper halves of the right and left sides of the design.

l.note: Lines 1-2, written on a piece of paper or tablet held by a hovering figure upper right, are from Genesis 5:24. Their English translation is "And Enoch walked with God" (Essick page 55). Sheila Spector points out "the omission in [the two figures'] text of the י (*yod*, symbol of the Divinity), which is the third letter (Trinity) of the first word (God) in the biblical text" (“Blake’s Graphic Use of Hebrew," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 37.2 [fall 2003]: 71). Hence, the correct spelling of this line would be "וא[י]ננו כי לקח".

This text appears just left of the inner margin of the verso of a leaf in an open book held by the central seated figure. English translation is "Enoch." As Sheila Spector explains, "While the lettering is lexigraphically correct, the text is located on the wrong half of the page. Because Hebrew is read from right to left, the name should either be in the center, as the title, or at the right margin." (“Blake’s Graphic Use of Hebrew”, *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 37.2 [fall 2003]: 70).
